Headline.Para: The humble rope - a tool in wildlife conservation

LeadPara.Para: On your next visit to Upper Seletar Reservoir in the Mandai area, look out for a thin rope stretching across the water.
You may catch a glimpse of a squirrel, or, if you are lucky, the rare Raffles' banded langur - a critically endangered monkey - using it as a bridge over the reservoir.

TailParas.Para: The rope bridge was installed last month by the National Parks Board (NParks). The Straits Times understands it is the first time NParks has installed one.

The rope bridge is part of a trial looking into ways of improving connectivity for animals to travel safely through fragmented landscapes, according to Dr Adrian Loo, NParks group director for conservation.
To provide animals with safe travel corridors, NParks has embarked on reforestation efforts, and planted native species along roadsides and in parks and nature areas.
"In areas where it is not possible to plant trees, for example across bodies of water, NParks is exploring arboreal connectivity options such as rope bridges," Dr Loo said.
Rope bridges could help animals that dwell in the forest canopy, such as squirrels and the Sunda slow loris, safely cross waterways and possibly even roads, he said.
If effective, it could play an important role in helping to connect Singapore's fragmented forested areas, providing linkways for animals which need to move around to look for food and mates.
Dr Loo said NParks will also be trying out other forms of rope bridges to assess their effectiveness and will consider installing them at other sites if they are successful.

Primate scientist Andie Ang, who chairs the Raffles' banded langur Working Group - a panel of researchers looking into ways of saving the monkey from extinction - said arboreal animals such as langurs rely on trees to travel and rarely come down to the ground.

"This is when artificial structures such as a rope bridge can help," said Dr Ang, noting that primates in other countries have been seen to use cable wires and ropes to cross between forest fragments.

Upper Seletar Reservoir was an ideal location to test out a rope bridge, she added, as the low human traffic there would minimise the risk of the rope breaking. "Utmost importance must be given to examining and refining the structure and integrity of the rope bridge and where it is attached to, such as trees or artificial poles, so that we do not cause injury to the animals using the bridge or vehicles and humans under the bridge."
The next step was to see which animals were using the rope, and what modifications can be made so subsequent versions are more effective.
"Rope ladders are inexpensive and easy to install, but have to be backed by data, before we start putting bridges between every forest fragment," said Dr Ang.

Article.Art: A rope linking two patches of forest across a water body at Mandai Road is seen here. The rope bridge is part of a trial by NParks which is looking into ways of improving connectivity for animals to travel safely through fragmented landscapes.
